page.title: 3.2.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will assess the fit of various lines to data, use technology to find the line of best fit, and interpret the slope and vertical intercept of the linear model. 

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Describe the rate of change and \(y\)-intercept for a linear model in everyday language.
  • Use technology to find the line of best fit.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 3.2.1: Selecting the Best Line
  • 3.2.2: Determining the Best Line That Fits the Data
  • 3.2.2: Self Check 
  • 3.2.3: Assessing the Fit of a Linear Model
  • 3.2.3: Self Check 
  • 3.2.4: Working with Fitted Lines

 After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 3.2.5: Practice
  • 3.2.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 3.2.1: Selecting the Best Line
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity


Which of the lines is the better fit for the data in each scatter plot? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The solid line is the better fit for the data since it goes through the middle of the data and follows the negative trend of the data with very few points a far distance from the line of best fit.


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The solid line is the better fit for the data since it goes through the middle of the data with approximately equal numbers of data points on either side of the line.




Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The dashed line is the better fit for the data since it goes through the middle of the data with a slope that follows the trend of the data. The solid line has a lot of points above the line to start and a lot of points below the line at the end.


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The dashed line is the better fit for the data since it goes through the middle of the data, follows the trend of the data, and has a similar number of points on each side that are not far from the line. The solid line fits the first and last point perfectly, but most of the data are above the line.

page.title: 3.2.2: Determining the Best Line That Fits the Data
page.contents:
Activity

Your teacher will give you a set of cards that show scatter plots.

Arrange all the cards in three different ways. Ensure that you and your partner agree on each arrangement before moving on to the next one. Sort all the cards in order from:

  1. best to worst for representing with a linear model
  2. least to greatest slope of a linear model that fits the data well
  3. least to greatest vertical intercept of a linear model that fits the data well

  1. Know that the line of best fit is the line that provides the best fit to the data. It should follow the trend of the data and go through the middle of the data with a similar number of points on each side of the line.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

  1. B, E, A and F, C, D, and G. There may be some debate about the exact order. It is important to recognize that B is the best fit, that D and G should not be fit with linear models, and that linear models fit more poorly the farther the data are from the line.
  2. E, B, A and F, C. D and G do not have linear models that fit the data well.
  3. A, C, F, B, E. D and G do not have linear models that fit the data well.

  1. For each card, write a sentence that describes how \(y\) changes as \(x\) increases and whether the linear model is a good fit for the data or not.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

  • Card A: As \(x\) increases, \(y\) also increases. The linear model fits the data fairly well.
  • Card B: As \(x\) increases, \(y\) decreases. The linear model fits the data very well.
  • Card C: As \(x\) increases, \(y\) increases. The linear model fits most of the data very well; however, there are two values that do not follow this trend.
  • Card D: As \(x\) increases, \(y\) goes up and down like a wave. The data do not follow the line very well at all.
  • Card E: As \(x\) increases, \(y\) decreases. Most of the data fit a linear model very well, but the one point at \((7,15)\) does not fit with the rest of the data very well.
  • Card F: As \(x\) increases, \(y\) increases. The linear model fits the data fairly well.
  • Card G: As \(x\) increases, \(y\) decreases and then increases. The data do not follow the line very well at all.

page.title: 3.2.2: Self Check
page.contents: Tell which line is the best fit for the data and give an explanation why it is the best fit.

answer.answer_text: Line 1 is the best fit because it touches the first point on the left of the scatter plot.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Where the line starts does not determine the line of best fit. The answer is line 2 is the best fit because it goes through the middle of the data with about the same number of data points above and below the line.

answer.answer_text: Line 2 is the best fit because it touches the last point on the right of the scatter plot.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Where the line ends does not determine its fit. The answer is line 2 is the best fit because it goes through the middle of the data with about the same number of data points above and below the line.

answer.answer_text: Line 2 is the best fit because it goes through the middle of the data with about the same number of data points above and below the line.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: Line 2 goes down the middle of the data and has almost the same number of points above and below the line.

answer.answer_text: Line 1 is the best fit because it has a steeper slope.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The steepness of the slope does not determine the line of best fit. The answer is line 2 is the best fit because it goes through the middle of the data with about the same number of data points above and below the line.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 3.2.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Draw a Best-Fit Line for the Plotted Data

When looking to draw a line of best fit, first make sure a linear model works for the data.

Next, place the line between the data points so that about the same number of points are above and below the line. The aim is to also have points within a close distance to the line of best fit.

Below are two examples of lines of best fit drawn through scatter plots.




Try It: Draw a Best-fit Line for the Plotted Data

The scatter plots below are the same scatter plot, but each student drew their best fit line differently. Which line do you believe to be the best fit, and why?

Enter your answer here.

Here is how to choose the best fitting line for the scatter plot:

Patti’s line looks like it fits the data well, so it would probably produce good predictions. The line goes through the middle of the points in the scatter plot, with a similar number of points above and below the line that are not a far distance from the line of best fit.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 3.2.3: Assessing the Fit of a Linear Model
page.contents:
Activity


The weight of ice cream sold at a small store in pounds (\(x\)) and the average temperature outside in degrees Celsius (\(y\)) are recorded in the table.

\(x\)

20

18

21

17

21.5

19.5

21

18

\(y\)

6

4.5

6.5

3.5

7.5

6.5

7

5


1. For these data, create a scatter plot by hand on a coordinate grid and sketch a line that fits the data well.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Answers vary. Lines should go through the middle of the data.



2. Now, use technology to create the scatter plot and compute the best fit line. Round any numbers to 2 decimal places.

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

\(y=0.78x−9.44\)




3. What are the values for the slope and \(y\)-intercept for the best fit line? What do these values mean in this situation?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The slope is 0.78, which means that about 1 additional pound of ice cream is sold with every 0.78-degree increase in the outside temperature. The \(y\)-intercept is \((0,-9.44)\), which means that no ice cream is sold when the temperature is about \(-9.44\) degrees Celsius.



4. Use the best fit line to predict the \(y\)-value when \(x\) is 10. Is this a good estimate for the data? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(-1.64\) degrees Celsius. Sample explanation: This may be a good estimate for the data since the points seem close to the line, but something different might happen when the temperature gets below freezing, so it’s possible that when only 10 pounds of ice cream are sold, the relationship with the weather may be different.


5. Your teacher will give you a data table for one of the other scatter plots from the previous activity. Use technology and this table of data to create a scatter plot that also shows the line of best fit. Then interpret the slope and \(y\)-intercept.

Compare your answer:

  • \(y=1.1979x+1.3196\). When \(x\) is zero, \(y\) is 1.3196. As \(x\) increases by 1, \(y\) increases, on average, by 1.1979.
  • \(y=-0.4337x+12.288\). When \(x\) is zero, \(y\) is 12.288. As \(x\) increases by 1, \(y\) decreases, on average, by 0.4337.
  • \(y=0.9749x+4.6529\). When \(x\) is zero, \(y\) is 4.6529. As \(x\) increases by 1, \(y\) increases, on average, by 0.9749.
  • \(y=-2.063x+16.144\). When \(x\) is zero, \(y\) is 16.144. As \(x\) increases by 1, \(y\) decreases, on average, by 2.063.
  • \(y=1.1979x+5.8196\). When \(x\) is zero, \(y\) is 5.8196. As \(x\) increases by 1, \(y\) increases, on average, by 1.1979.



Video: Finding Lines of Best Fit

Watch the following video to learn more about finding appropriate lines of best fit with the help of technology.



Making a Real-World Connection 

Priya uses several different ride services to get around her city. The table shows the distance, in miles, she traveled during her last 10 trips and the price of each trip, in dollars.

distance (miles)

price ($)

31.

12.5

4.2

14.75

5

16

3.5

13.25

2.5

12

1

9

0.8

8.75

1.6

9.75

4.3

12

3.3

14

  1. Priya creates a scatter plot of the data using the distance, \(x\), and the price, \(y\). She determines that a linear model is appropriate to use with the data. Use technology to find the equation of a line of best fit.
  2. Interpret the slope and the \(y\)-intercept of the equation of the line of best fit in this situation.
  3. Use the line of best fit to estimate the cost of a 3.6-mile trip. Will this estimate be close to the actual value? Explain your reasoning.
  4. On her next trip, Priya tries a new ride service and travels 3.6 miles, but she pays only $4.00 because she receives a discount. Include this trip in the table and calculate the equation of the line of best fit for the 11 trips. Did the slope of the equation of the line of best fit increase, decrease, or stay the same? Why? Explain your reasoning.
  5. Priya uses the new ride service for her 12th trip. She travels 4.1 miles and is charged $24.75. How do you think the slope of the equation 

Enter your answers here:

Your answers may vary, but here are some sample responses to compare your answers.

  1. \(y=1.57x+7.6\) 
  2. Sample response: The slope means that the fare increases by $1.57 for each additional mile driven. The \(y\)-intercept means that the fee for getting in the car is approximately $7.60.
  3. Sample response: According to the line of best fit, the cost of a 3.6-mile trip is approximately $13.25, which is the same price as the 3.5-mile trip listed in the table.
  4. Sample response: The slope of the line decreased to $1.27 for each additional mile. It probably decreased because $4.00 is a far lower price per mile than any of her other trips because of the discount. This causes the slope, the increase in price for each additional mile, to decrease.
  5. Sample response: The slope of the line will probably increase because $24.75 is very expensive and will likely cause the cost for each additional mile to increase.

page.title: 3.2.3: Self Check
page.contents:
Old Faithful is a geyser in Yellowstone National Park. The following table offers some rough estimates of the length of an eruption (in minutes) and the amount of water (in gallons) in that eruption.

Length (minutes)

1.5

2

3

4.5

Amount of Water (gallons)

3,700

4,100

6,450

8,400

Use technology to find an equation of the line of best fit. Round to the nearest hundredth.

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The slope of the line is the coefficient of \(x\). The answer is \(y  = 640.48x+1151.19\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This was found using the first two points in the table. Use technology to enter the data from the table then find the linear regression line. The answer is \(y  = 1640.48x+1151.19\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The slope of the line is the coefficient of \(x\). The \(y\)-intercept would be below 3,700 with the linear trend.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The trend is increasing in the table, so the slope should be positive. The answer is \(y=1640.48x+1151.19\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 3.2.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Technology for Best Fitting Lines

Scientists are interested in finding out how different species adapt to finding food sources. One group studied crocodilians to find out how their bite force was related to body mass and diet. The table below displays the information they collected on body mass (in pounds) and bite force (in pounds). 

Crocodilian Biting

The scatter plot below displays the data on body mass and bite force for the crocodilians in the study. 

Using technology, the line of best fit for the data is \(y=3.02x +154.68\).

The slope of the line of best fit is 3.02. This signifies that for every pound more the crocodile weighs, it has 3.02 more pounds of bite force.

The \(y\)-intercept is 154.68, which doesn’t quite make sense for a crocodile that weighs 0 pounds, but it does give a minimum bite force to expect from a crocodile.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 3.2.4: Working with Fitted Lines
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

1. Which of these scatter plots shows data that would best be modeled with a linear function? Explain your reasoning.



Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

C. The points in the scatter plot seem to follow the shape of a line best. The scatter plot in A is very spread out, and the scatter plot in B is probably better fit by a curve.


2. Which of the following lines is most likely the line of best fit for the data provided?

        • \(y=-0.51x+225.12\)
        • \(y=0.34x−34.05\)
        • \(y=0.13x−0.19\)
        • \(y=0.98x−21.13\)

page.title: 3.2.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

1. Question 1 (Technology required.)


\(x\)

\(y\)

83

102

87

115

91

107

93

122

97

125

97

127

101

120

104

127

Use graphing technology to create a scatter plot and find the best fit line.
What does the best fit line estimate for the \(y\)-value when \(x\) is 100?

Correct! The line of best fit is \(y=1.089x+15.588\), so when \(x\) is 100, \(y\) is about 125.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 3.2.2–3.23. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer for the line of best fit is \(y=1.089x+15.588\), so when \(x\) is 100, \(y\) is about 125. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


2. A seed is planted in a glass pot, and its height is measured in centimeters every day.


The best fit line is given by the equation \(y=0.404x−5.18\), where \(y\) represents the height of the plant above ground level, and \(x\) represents the number of days since it was planted.

What is the slope of the best fit line? What does the slope of the line mean in this situation? 

Correct! The slope is 0.404, which means for every day, the plant grows 0.404 centimeters. 

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 3.2.2–3.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The slope is 0.404, which means for every day, the plant grows 0.404 centimeters. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

3. The scatter plots below show different lines that students used to model the relationship between body mass (in pounds) and bite force (in pounds) for crocodiles.

Match each graph to one of the equations below, and explain your reasoning. Let \(B\) represent bite force (in pounds) and \(W\) represent body mass (in pounds).



Equation 1: \(B = 3.28W +126 \)

Correct! Line 3 and Equation 1 match because the intercept of Equation 1 is the smallest, which seems to match the graph.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 3.2.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: Line 3 and Equation 1 match because the intercept of Equation 1 is the smallest, which seems to match the graph. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

b. Equation 2: \(B = 3.04W +351\)

Correct! Line 2 and Equation 2 match because the intercept of Equation 2 is larger, so it matches Line 2, which has a \(y\)-intercept closer to 400.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 3.2.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: Line 2 and Equation 2 match because the intercept of Equation 2 is larger, so it matches Line 2, which has a \(y\)-intercept closer to 400. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


c. Equation 3: \(B = 2.16W +267\)

Correct! Line 1 and Equation 3 match because the intercept of 267 appears to match the graph, which has the second-largest intercept.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 3.2.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: Line 1 and Equation 3 match because the intercept of 267 appears to match the graph, which has the second-largest intercept. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 3.2.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Describe the rate of change and \(y\)-intercept for a linear model in everyday language.
  • Use technology to find the line of best fit.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  •  3.2.1: Selecting the Best Line
    • In this activity, you visually assessed the best line fit for data among a set of given choices. You explored bad fit, good fit, and best fit.
  • 3.2.2: Determining the Best Line That Fits the Data
    • In this activity, you distinguished between linear and nonlinear relationships in bivariate, numerical data and informally assessed the fit of a linear model. You also compared the slope and the vertical intercepts of different linear models and were able to describe the relationship between two variables.
  • 3.2.2: Self Check 
  • 3.2.3: Assessing the Fit of a Linear Model
    • In this activity, you used technology to compute a line of best fit for data given in a table and to recognize the meaning of the slope and \(y\)-intercept.
  • 3.2.3: Self Check 
  • 3.2.4: Working with Fitted Lines
    • In this activity, you had an opportunity to work with fitted lines. You identified scatter plots that showed data that would best be modeled with a linear function and the line of best fit for the data provided.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 3.2.5: Practice

Checking In 

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
